criteria: Understanding of long-term causes (e.g., mercantilism, Enlightenment ideas, the Great Awakening).
Knowledge of short-term causes/events (e.g., Stamp Act, Tea Act, Intolerable Acts, Boston Massacre).
Explanation of colonial grievances and resistance.
descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of the long-term causes of the American Revolution.
Identifies one long-term cause with minimal explanation.
Identifies two long-term causes with superficial explanations.
Identifies three long-term causes with basic explanations but lacks depth.
Explains at least three long-term causes with good detail and connections to colonial discontent.
Provides a comprehensive explanation of multiple long-term causes, demonstrating a deep understanding of their impact on the growing tensions between Britain and the colonies.
Demonstrates no knowledge of the short-term causes or events leading to the Revolution.
Identifies one short-term cause/event with minimal accuracy.
Identifies two short-term causes/events with some inaccuracies.
Identifies three short-term causes/events with basic accuracy.
Accurately explains several short-term causes/events and their impact on colonial sentiment.
Provides a detailed and accurate explanation of numerous short-term causes/events, demonstrating a strong understanding of their role in escalating the conflict.
Unable to identify any colonial grievances or forms of resistance.
Identifies a single grievance or act of resistance with little explanation.
Identifies multiple grievances or acts of resistance but struggles to explain their significance.
Explains some key grievances and resistance efforts, such as boycotts and protests.
Clearly explains the major grievances and various forms of colonial resistance, connecting them to the causes of the Revolution.
Provides a nuanced explanation of colonial grievances and resistance, demonstrating a deep understanding of colonial motivations and strategies.
